instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot
threads.message:
Hi, new to the forum and have been reading some of the posts on the <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> and not feeling good about getting this one. Device had battery changed by another tech and now will not power up. Below are the voltage measurements. <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 0 which I think is due to <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> being at 61mv. <RESISTOR>R7810</RESISTOR> resistance measures fine and did not find anything out of the ordinary with diode mode. Tracing back on the schematics I think the issue could be with <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> but wanted some expert advice on where I might go next to validate. I do not have an Oscope to check clock signals. Thanks in advance.

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.09
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.07
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.34
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.35
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.34
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 3.32
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 61mv
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.34
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 0

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

What is the exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage?
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> at same time.

<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> can be pulled down by <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, SMC, or PCH.
Check <SIGNAL>PCH_RTCRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot
threads.message:
Thanks for the welcome and the help. 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  = 8.72

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>  dropped to .3 from 3.3 when  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>  triggered

<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>  = 2.57 (seems low to me)
<SIGNAL>PCH_RTCRST_L</SIGNAL>  = 3.07
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.08

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> is good enough.

"when  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>  triggered"
Do you mean <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?
If yes, PCH receives the power button information from SMC, but cannot reply while <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> is pulled down.
Post diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> with red probe at ground.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot
threads.message:
sorry, yes I meant <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>  diode measurement is .415

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot
threads.message:
You can try replacing SMC and <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.
If <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> still low, then bad PCH (CPU)...

You should already know the CPU on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board doesn't have long life...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot
threads.message: Thanks and I have read a lot on here about these CPUs so hoping it is not.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot
threads.message: Thanks again for all of your help. One more question. Do you know where I can find the ICs? I have been unable to locate them.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot
threads.message: <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> and SMC for the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no boot
threads.message:
SMC MUST be from donor board, same model.
I don't know if <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> has specific firmware for particular board; maybe not, need to try...
